page.title: 17LANDSCAPE CHANGES
page.content: The quarrying at Fledmyre has changed the{landscape. Some of the{water supply}for processing the sand and gravel is taken from the bog at Pitscandly and the rest is pumped from the ground to the quarry. The clean water is pumped into a pool about 30 feet deep. Then it is taken from the pool and put into a machine which washes the silt off the sand and gravel. The silt and dirty water are put into holes which form sludge beds. As they are quarrying they are continuously{ {infilling}the land by topping up the holes with rubbish and{restoring}the land by putting black top soil on the top so the farmer can reclaim it. Meanwhile the owner of the land receives royalties for every ton of sand and gravel which leaves the quarry.
